name: smith
content:
smith

noun
 
/smɪθ/
 
/smɪθ/
(also blacksmith)
jump to other results
  1. a person whose job is to make and repair things made of iron, especially horseshoes see also goldsmith, gunsmith, locksmith, silversmithTopics Jobsc2
    Word OriginOld English, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch smid and German Schmied.
See smith in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: smith

name: Smith
content:
Smith

 
/smɪθ/
 
/smɪθ/
jump to other results
  1. a very common family name in Britain and the US. It is sometimes used by people who do not want their real names to be known.
    • They had registered at the hotel in the names of Mr and Mrs Smith.
Check pronunciation: Smith

name: blacksmith
content:
blacksmith

noun
 
/ˈblæksmɪθ/
 
/ˈblæksmɪθ/
(also smith)
jump to other results
  1. a person whose job is to make and repair things made of iron, especially horseshoes compare farrierTopics Jobsc2
    Oxford Collocations DictionaryBlacksmith is used after these nouns:
    • village
    See full entry

name: Smith's
content:
Smith's

 
/smɪθs/
 
/smɪθs/
jump to other results
  1. WH Smith
Check pronunciation: Smith's

name: WH Smith
content:
WH Smith

 
/ˌdʌbljuː eɪtʃ ˈsmɪθ/
 
/ˌdʌbljuː eɪtʃ ˈsmɪθ/
(also also informal Smith's)
jump to other results
  1. a large group of British shops selling newspapers, magazines, books, cards, toys and games, etc. Many British towns have a branch of Smith's. There are also hundreds of branches of Smith's at train stations, airports, etc. in the UK and Ireland, and branches in Australia, Asia and the Middle East. The first shop using the Smith family name opened in 1792 and the company WH Smith was founded in 1828.
Check pronunciation: WH Smith

name: Adam Smith
content:
Adam Smith

 
/ˌædəm ˈsmɪθ/
 
/ˌædəm ˈsmɪθ/
jump to other results
  1. (1723-90) a Scottish philosopher and economist. He believed in free trade and private enterprise (= the idea that business and industry should be controlled by private individuals or companies, not by the state). His book, The Wealth of Nations, is regarded as the first major work in the modern science of economics. His ideas have influenced several politicians in modern times, including Margaret Thatcher and Gordon Brown.
Check pronunciation: Adam Smith

name: Ian Smith
content:
Ian Smith

 
/ˌiːən ˈsmɪθ/
 
/ˌiːən ˈsmɪθ/
jump to other results
  1. (1919-2007) the last prime minister of Rhodesia, the country now called Zimbabwe. In 1965 he declared Rhodesia to be an independent African country ruled by white people. Although very few countries recognized Rhodesia, Smith stayed in charge until the country became Zimbabwe in 1979.
Check pronunciation: Ian Smith

name: John Smith
content:
John Smith

 
/ˌdʒɒn ˈsmɪθ/
 
/ˌdʒɑːn ˈsmɪθ/
jump to other results
  1. (c. 1579-1631) an English colonist (= a person who establishes a colony, an area settled and controlled by people from another country) in America. He was one of the early colonists in Virginia, and was president of the North American colony from 1608 to 1609. In 1614 he explored New England, and gave it its name. He traded goods with Native Americans, and is best known for the story that his life was saved by the Native-American princess Pocahontas.
  2. (1938-94) a Scottish Labour politician. He became Leader of the Opposition in 1992. In 1993 he was responsible for changing the way decisions are made in the Labour Party by giving each party member and trade union member one vote. Before that, the unions had always voted for all their members. When he died Tony Blair became leader of the Labour Party.
Check pronunciation: John Smith

name: Kate Smith
content:
Kate Smith

 
/ˌkeɪt ˈsmɪθ/
 
/ˌkeɪt ˈsmɪθ/
jump to other results
  1. (1909-86) a US singer. She became famous during the Second World War for her version of God Bless America and for travelling thousands of miles to entertain the military forces. Smith recorded about 3 000 songs including her theme song, When the Moon Comes Over the Mountain, which began her radio shows in the 1930s and the 1940s. She later had her own television series, (1950-56).
Check pronunciation: Kate Smith

name: Granny Smith
content:
Granny Smith

noun
 
/ˌɡræni ˈsmɪθ/
 
/ˌɡræni ˈsmɪθ/
jump to other results
  1. a type of green apple
    Word Originlate 19th cent.: named after Maria Ann (Granny) Smith (c.1801–1870), who first produced such apples.
See Granny Smith in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: Granny Smith

name: Bessie Smith
content:
Bessie Smith

 
/ˌbesi ˈsmɪθ/
 
/ˌbesi ˈsmɪθ/
jump to other results
  1. (1895-1937) the leading African Americanblues singer of her time. Her popular name was 'Empress of the Blues'. During her career, she performed with such musicians as Benny Goodman, Louis Armstrong and Fletcher Henderson. Her hits included Downhearted Blues (1923). She died after a car crash.
Check pronunciation: Bessie Smith

name: Joseph Smith
content:
Joseph Smith

 
/ˌdʒəʊzəf ˈsmɪθ/,
 
/ˌdʒəʊsəf ˈsmɪθ/
 
/ˌdʒəʊzəf ˈsmɪθ/,
 
/ˌdʒəʊsəf ˈsmɪθ/
jump to other results
  1. (1805-44) the US religious leader who started the Mormon Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints and published The Book of Mormon (1830) containing their basic beliefs. After some of his followers burnt down the offices of a Mormon newspaper that had criticized him, Smith was arrested with his brother Hyrum and taken to a prison at Carthage, Illinois, where an angry crowd shot and killed them.
Check pronunciation: Joseph Smith

name: Stevie Smith
content:
Stevie Smith

 
/ˌstiːvi ˈsmɪθ/
 
/ˌstiːvi ˈsmɪθ/
jump to other results
  1. (1902-71) an English writer of poems and novels. She wrote three novels but is best known for the harsh and intelligent humour of her poetry. Her most famous poem is Not Waving but Drowning (1957).
Check pronunciation: Stevie Smith

name: Sydney Smith
content:
Sydney Smith

 
/ˌsɪdni ˈsmɪθ/
 
/ˌsɪdni ˈsmɪθ/
jump to other results
  1. (1771-1845) an English writer and Church of England priest. He played an important role in social and political campaigns such as Catholic emancipation and the abolition of slavery. He was also famous for making remarks full of clever humour.
Check pronunciation: Sydney Smith

name: Smith Square
content:
Smith Square

 
/ˌsmɪθ ˈskweə(r)/
 
/ˌsmɪθ ˈskwer/
jump to other results
  1. a square in central London, near the Houses of Parliament. Until 2004 it was the address of the main offices of the Conservative Party. People sometimes used 'Smith Square' to refer to the party's central office
Check pronunciation: Smith Square

name: Smith & Wesson
content:
Smith & Wesson

 
/ˌsmɪθ ən ˈwesn/
 
/ˌsmɪθ ən ˈwesn/
jump to other results
  1. a company that makes guns, and also knives and bicycles. It was established in 1852 in Springfield, Massachusetts, by Horace Smith (1808-93) and Daniel B Wesson (1825-1906).
    • He had been shot at close range by a Smith & Wesson handgun.
Check pronunciation: Smith & Wesson

name: Margaret Chase Smith
content:
Margaret Chase Smith

 
/ˌmɑːɡrət tʃeɪs ˈsmɪθ/
 
/ˌmɑːrɡrət tʃeɪs ˈsmɪθ/
jump to other results
  1. (1897-1995) the first US woman elected to both the US House of Representatives (1940-49) and the US Senate (1949-73). She was also, in 1964, the first woman to be named by a major political party as a possible candidate for US President. Smith was a member of the Republican Party from Maine.
Check pronunciation: Margaret Chase Smith

name: the Adam Smith Institute
content:
the Adam Smith Institute

 
/ði ˌædəm ˈsmɪθ ɪnstɪtjuːt/
 
/ði ˌædəm ˈsmɪθ ɪnstɪtuːt/
jump to other results
  1. a British organization formed in 1977 to give economic advice to the British government, foreign governments and other groups. It was named after the 18th-century economist Adam Smith, and shared many of his ideas (for example, about the importance of reducing the extent to which the state is involved in social and commercial affairs). It was associated particularly with the Conservative governments of the 1980s and 1990s in Britain.
Check pronunciation: the Adam Smith Institute
